repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #2905 by raising the sys_path resolution into Context.search_include_directories

Also fix a bug in calling `os.path.join` with identical paths which merges them when they are absolute paths but concatenates them when they are relative paths, causing the test which adds a relative path to `sys.path` to fail. This would only occur when searching for `__init__.pxd`.

comment_data.body: I don't think you need `os.path.normpath` here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,6 +40,8 @@
 
 verbose = 0
 
+standard_include_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.normpath(

comment_data.body:
It might be cleaner to write this as
```
include_dirs = self.include_directories
if sys_path:
    include_dirs = include_dirs + tuple(sys.path)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,8 +251,13 @@ def find_include_file(self, filename, pos):
 
     def search_include_directories(self, qualified_name, suffix, pos,
                                    include=False, sys_path=False):
-        return search_include_directories(
-            tuple(self.include_directories), qualified_name, suffix, pos, include, sys_path)
+        if sys_path:
+            include_dirs = self.include_directories + tuple(sys.path)
+        else:
+            include_dirs = self.include_directories

comment_data.body: It seems to me that this llong comment belongs in the PR discussion, not in the code. There is no point in explaining why the old code was wrong, you need to explain why the new code is right.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -648,7 +649,18 @@ def search_include_directories(dirs, qualified_name, suffix, pos,
                 path = os.path.join(package_dir, module_filename)
                 if os.path.exists(path):
                     return path
-                path = os.path.join(dirname, package_dir, module_name,
+                # In most cases, dirname and package_dir will be the same.
+                # From the documentation of os.path.join:
+                # " If a component is an absolute path, all previous components
+                # are thrown away and joining continues from the absolute path
+                # component"
+                # So if dirname and package_dir are absolute pathes, one will
+                # be discarded. However what happens when they are relative
+                # single-component paths? They will be concatenated (repeated),
+                # causing rare and hard to debug problems.
+                # path = os.path.join(dirname, package_dir, module_name,
+                #                    package_filename)

comment_data.body: No idea. As far as I can tell, this code path is only used by `Cython/Build/BuildExecutable.py`
Not sure what you two mean here. What suffix is missing where? The `name` shouldn't have one, and the lookups don't expect one.
Does this really need to be a tuple? It seems like it should rather be a list, at least at this point, but also generally. Make a copy when necessary, but why use a tuple?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,7 +68,7 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         self.modules = {"__builtin__" : Builtin.builtin_scope}
         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

comment_data.body: ok, will remove the comments
ok
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -648,7 +649,18 @@ def search_include_directories(dirs, qualified_name, suffix, pos,
                 path = os.path.join(package_dir, module_filename)
                 if os.path.exists(path):
                     return path
-                path = os.path.join(dirname, package_dir, module_name,
+                # In most cases, dirname and package_dir will be the same.
+                # From the documentation of os.path.join:
+                # " If a component is an absolute path, all previous components
+                # are thrown away and joining continues from the absolute path
+                # component"
+                # So if dirname and package_dir are absolute pathes, one will
+                # be discarded. However what happens when they are relative
+                # single-component paths? They will be concatenated (repeated),
+                # causing rare and hard to debug problems.
+                # path = os.path.join(dirname, package_dir, module_name,
+                #                    package_filename)

comment_data.body: ok
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,6 +40,8 @@
 
 verbose = 0
 
+standard_include_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.normpath(

comment_data.body: ok, changing to list

         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

comment_data.body: adopted

                                    include=False, sys_path=False):
-        return search_include_directories(
-            tuple(self.include_directories), qualified_name, suffix, pos, include, sys_path)
+        if sys_path:

comment_data.body: it has to be a tuple to be hashable. Reverting
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,7 +68,7 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         self.modules = {"__builtin__" : Builtin.builtin_scope}
         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

comment_data.body: Where do you need it to be hashable?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,7 +68,7 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         self.modules = {"__builtin__" : Builtin.builtin_scope}
         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

@@ -66,7 +68,7 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         self.modules = {"__builtin__" : Builtin.builtin_scope}
         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

comment_data.body:
Then it's probably enough to convert it into a tuple right before passing it into the function, right?
I mean, the right solution might actually be to convert everything to tuples inside of `cached_function()`, but in any case, we shouldn't use surprising data structures in multiple places just because one place that uses them requires a certain type as a side-effect of an optimisation.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,7 +68,7 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         self.modules = {"__builtin__" : Builtin.builtin_scope}
         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

comment_data.body: Probably worth giving a hint why this was done (and keeping the two empty lines before the next version section).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -115,6 +115,10 @@ Other changes
 
 * Support for Python 2.6 was removed.
 
+* The search order for include files was changed. Previously it was
+  ``include_directories``, ``Cython/Includes``, ``sys.path``. Now it is
+  ``include_directories``, ``sys.path``, ``Cython/Includes``. (Github issue
+  #2905)

comment_data.body: Would you prefer `args = [tuple(x) for x in args if isinstance(x, list) else x]` in `cached_function`? I reduced the "multiple places to the call to `search_include_directories` and added a comment.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,7 +68,7 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         self.modules = {"__builtin__" : Builtin.builtin_scope}
         self.cython_scope = CythonScope.create_cython_scope(self)
         self.modules["cython"] = self.cython_scope
-        self.include_directories = include_directories
+        self.include_directories = tuple(include_directories)

comment_data.body: ok

comment_data.body: `__index__.pxd` ? You probably meant to use some generic name like `special_library.pxd`, right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,8 +117,10 @@ Other changes
 
 * The search order for include files was changed. Previously it was
   ``include_directories``, ``Cython/Includes``, ``sys.path``. Now it is
-  ``include_directories``, ``sys.path``, ``Cython/Includes``. (Github issue
-  #2905)
+  ``include_directories``, ``sys.path``, ``Cython/Includes``. This was done to
+  allow third-party `__index__.pxd` files to override the ones in Cython.

comment_data.body: No need for the trailing comma in lists.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -251,10 +251,11 @@ def find_include_file(self, filename, pos):
 
     def search_include_directories(self, qualified_name, suffix, pos,
                                    include=False, sys_path=False):
-        include_dirs = tuple(self.include_directories)
+        include_dirs = self.include_directories
         if sys_path:
-            include_dirs = include_dirs + tuple(sys.path)
-        include_dirs = include_dirs + (standard_include_path,)
+            include_dirs = include_dirs + sys.path
+        # include_dirs must be hashable for caching in @cached_function
+        include_dirs = tuple(include_dirs + [standard_include_path,])

comment_data.body: changed to `*.pxd`

 * The search order for include files was changed. Previously it was
   ``include_directories``, ``Cython/Includes``, ``sys.path``. Now it is
-  ``include_directories``, ``sys.path``, ``Cython/Includes``. (Github issue

comment_data.body: fixed
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -251,10 +251,11 @@ def find_include_file(self, filename, pos):
 
     def search_include_directories(self, qualified_name, suffix, pos,
                                    include=False, sys_path=False):
-        include_dirs = tuple(self.include_directories)
+        include_dirs = self.include_directories
         if sys_path:
-            include_dirs = include_dirs + tuple(sys.path)
-        include_dirs = include_dirs + (standard_include_path,)
+            include_dirs = include_dirs + sys.path
+        # include_dirs must be hashable for caching in @cached_function
+        include_dirs = tuple(include_dirs + [standard_include_path,])

commit.message: BUG: prefer sys.path before Cython/Include when searching for pxd files

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: BUG: prefer sys.path before Cython/Include when searching for pxd files
